Award.AwardTitle: Southern Regional Algebra Conference 2017: Computational Methods in Algebra and Representation Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Southern Regional Algebra Conference 2017 will be held March 17-19, 2017 on the campus of the University of South Alabama in Mobile, Alabama. The Southern Regional Algebra Conference is an annual weekend algebra conference that has been in existence since 1988. It serves an important role for the research community in algebra in the Gulf Coast Region. The highlighted theme for this year's conference will be computational methods in algebra and representation theory. This conference will broaden the appeal of an already successful program and increase participation of graduate students, early-career mathematicians, researchers at institutions that serve under-represented groups, and faculty at primarily undergraduate institutions. The long-term goal of the conference series is to build a strong network of algebraists that fosters collaboration in research and education.

The availability of ever increasing computational capabilities has led to new insights in many research areas in algebra. At this conference, two leading experts on computational methods will present their work in plenary talks. Together with formal and informal follow-up discussions, these will facilitate interactions between experts on computational methods and theoretical researchers. In addition, there will be twenty to thirty talks covering a wide spectrum of research topics in algebra. The conference website is http://www.southalabama.edu/colleges/artsandsci/mathstat/srac/index.html.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT FOR NSF GRANT 1702001 SOUTHERN REGIONAL ALGEBRA CONFERENCE 2017 (SRAC 2017) COMPUTATIONAL METHODS IN ALGEBRA AND REPRESENTATION THEORY

Overview

The Southern Regional Algebra Conference 2017 (SRAC 2017) was held on March 17 - 19, 2017, on the campus of the University of South Alabama (USA). Here is a quick overview.  

A total of 89 participants from 37 different institutions (16 Ph.D. Granting, 5 Masters, 14 Undergraduate, 1 Community College, 1 High School)

Two plenary talks: Computing with Matrix and Basic Algebras by Jon Carlson, University of Georgia, and Basic Algorithms in the Representation Theory of Groups and Algebras by Klaus Lux, University of Arizona. 

A total of 48 additional speakers in two parallel sessions.

NSF funds were used to support or partially support 43 participants, including the 2 principal speakers, 22 graduate students, 5 post-docs, 12 non-tenured/junior faculty, 1 visiting scholar, 1 associate professor.

Conference proceedings will be published under the title Advances in Algebra - Research from the Southern Regional Algebra Conference 2017 in the series Proceedings in Mathematics & Statistics by Springer Verlag.

SRAC 2018 will be held in April 2018 at Auburn University at Montgomery. 

Broadening Participation: The University of South Alabama hosted the Southern Regional Algebra Conference in 2009. The 2009 conference had approximately 45 participants and 24 speakers. By comparison, in 2017, the number of participants and speakers doubled. Clearly, the availability of supporting funds from the NSF played an important role. Note that more than half of the participants in the conference survey indicated that the availability of external funding was important in regards to their ability to attend. Approximately 30% of the participants were graduate students,  31% were non-tenured or junior faculty, most from mainly undergraduate institutions, and 8% were postdocs. In total, 37 different institutions were represented.  About 28% of those participants receiving financial support were female. The willingness of many participants to share hotel rooms and transportation made it possible to support a large number of attendees. 

Scientific Merit: At the center of the program were two well-received plenary talks Computing with Matrix and Basic Algebras by Jon Carlson and Basic Algorithms in the Representation Theory of Groups and Algebras by Klaus Lux, two leading experts on computational methods in algebra and representation theory. In addition there were 48 25-minute talks, organized in two parallel sessions, including 9 presentations by graduate students. Leonard Scott from the University of Virginia gave a nice survey on his work with an undergraduate student on computing Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials. He spoke on recent computational results that lead to surprising new insights on group representations. In addition Josh Maglione, a graduate student from Colorado State, spoke on new efficient algorithms on computing isomorphism invariant subgroups. Computing with Groebner basis was the subject of a talk by John Perry from the University of Southern Mississippi.  Other talks covered both theoretical as well as computational aspects in ring theory, group theory, Lie theory,  commutative algebra, algebraic geometry, linear algebra, quantum groups and other research areas in algebra. According to the conference survey, 68% of respondents rated the overall quality of the scientific program as excellent, 29% rated it as good.  The plenary talks received similar ratings. The conference program and the conference abstracts are available at the conference website.

Dissemination and Collaboration: The conference organizers signed an agreement with Springer Verlag to publish conference proceedings as part of Springer's series Proceedings in Mathematics & Statistics. The volume will consist of 15 to 20 research and survey articles by conference participants, including contributions by the plenary speakers. The volume is to be submitted by July 2018.

Presentations by  graduate students at the conference have led to several job interviews and job offers at other participating institutions. The organizers updated and continue to maintain the conference email list. They work closely with the organizers of SRAC 2018, to be held in April 2018 at Auburn University at Montgomery.
